summary: This is an internal FBI email chain from April 2020 discussing case progress and forensic backlogs. It mentions the Epstein and Maxwell investigations, the Nygard case, and a 'Ray' case, focusing on delays in processing digital evidence due to CART (Computer Analysis and Response Team) limitations during reduced office work.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Mentioned as the subject of a pending prosecution memorandum (pros memo) that SONY (likely SDNY - Southern District of New York) is expected to approve.

events.title: Email update on case progress
events.description: Internal FBI email states there is nothing new on the Epstein investigation and that SONY (SDNY) will approve a prosecution memo on Ghislaine Maxwell. The email also discusses a backlog in processing digital evidence for the Nygard case.

events.title: Discussion of CART backlog
events.description: An earlier email describes a significant backlog in the FBI's CART unit for processing forensic evidence from the Epstein, Nygard, and Ray cases, exacerbated by agents only being in the office 1-2 days a week.

locations: NY (New York, likely referring to the FBI's New York Field Office or SDNY)
SONY (interpreted as Southern District of New York - SDNY)
keyFacts: The email indicates the investigation into Ghislaine Maxwell was active in April 2020, with a prosecution memorandum pending approval from SDNY.
The FBI's Computer Analysis and Response Team (CART) was experiencing a significant backlog in processing digital evidence for high-priority cases including Epstein, Nygard, and Ray.
The backlog was partly due to reduced office presence (1-2 days a week) during the time period, likely related to the COVID-19 pandemic.
The email chain is focused on coordinating forensic review efforts between the FBI case team and the US Attorney's Office (SDNY).
Multiple names of FBI personnel are redacted in the document, indicating internal law enforcement discussions.
